trans-unit.source: Provides a programmable control for displaying larger amounts of text, with optional markup tags on a mobile page.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Unlike literal text in a mobile form, you can set content of a TextView from code.
Unlike a mobile <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Label> control, you can include markup within the value of the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.Text%2A> property.
Also, the TextView control is careful not to break up inserted elements such as links during pagination.
For more information, see [Literal Text Inside Form Markup](http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/05e061ed-9916-4ece-bfc8-7bf131fe232e).

If the TextView control is within a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel>, set the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel.Paginate%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property to `true` to allow text to flow across multiple pages on mobile devices.

If the TextView control is not in a <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Panel>, put the name of the TextView control into the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.Form.ControlToPaginate%2A?displayProperty=fullName> property.
Most other properties and methods of the mobile TextView control are of more use to developers of new device adapters for rendering the contents on specific devices.
> [!CAUTION] > This control can be used to display user input, which might include malicious client script.
Check any information that is sent from a client for executable script, SQL statements, or other code before displaying it in your application.
You can use validation controls to verify user input before displaying the input text in a control.
ASP.NET provides an input request validation feature to block script and HTML in user input.

For more information, see [Securing Standard Controls](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md), [How to: Protect Against Script Exploits in a Web Application by Applying HTML Encoding to Strings](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md), and [Validating User Input in ASP.NET Web Pages](~/add/includes/ajax-current-ext-md.md).
Initializes a new instance of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref> class.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
Gets the index of the first <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> object on the current text view after the text is paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The FirstVisibleElementIndex property is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
The index of the first <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> object on the current text view when the text view is paginated.
If there are no <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> objects for the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref> object, returns -1.
Gets the character offset into the first <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> class, which is displayed when paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The FirstVisibleElementOffset property is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
The character offset into the first <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> class, which is displayed when paginated.
If there are no <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> objects for the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref> object, this value is 0.
Returns the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> class at the given index.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The GetElement method is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
The index of the <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> class.
The <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> at the given index.
Gets the number of items in the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The number of items in the control.
Gets or sets the number of items in the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The number of items in the control.
Sets or returns the number of items displayed per page after pagination.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The ItemsPerPage property is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
If zero, pagination is not affected by this property.
If nonzero, overrides items displayed per page when the form is paginated.
The default value is zero.
Mobile controls that support internal pagination also provide a feature called custom pagination.
Normally, such controls require you to provide them all the data that they can display.
Developers specify the total number of items that are in the list in the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView.ItemCount%2A> property.
The ItemsPerPage property specifies how many items the control displays per page.
The number of items displayed per page after pagination.
Gets the approximate weight of a single item in the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The approximate weight of a single item in the control.
Returns the index of the last <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> object on the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref> object.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The LastVisibleElementIndex property is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
The index of the last <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> on the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref>.
If there are no <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> objects on the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref>, returns 0.
Returns the character offset into the last <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> object, which is displayed when paginated.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The LastVisibleElementOffset property is used by developers of custom device adapters for rendering the contents.
The character offset into the last <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> object, which is displayed when paginated.
If there are no <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextViewElement"></xref> objects on the current <xref href="System.Web.UI.MobileControls.TextView"></xref>, returns 0.
Occurs when a control is custom-paginated and needs more data.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
When control is custom-paginated, you do not explicitly bind the control.
After pagination, the control raises this event, indicating what part of the data is required.
The application can handle this event and bind the control with the required data.
To be added.
Raises the <xref:System.Web.UI.MobileControls.MobileControl.Render*> event.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
An <xref href="System.Web.UI.HtmlTextWriter"></xref> that will render the content.
Paginates the control and its children.
Called internally by ASP.NET.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The pager.
Sets or returns the text for the control.
This API is obsolete.
For information about how to develop ASP.NET mobile applications, see the [www.asp.net/mobile](http://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=182900) Web site.
The text for the control.
